title: Articles: a / an
description: Use *a* and *an* before singular, countable nouns when the listener/reader does not already know which specific thing you mean. Choose *a* before a consonant sound and *an* before a vowel sound. Because English spelling and pronunciation do not always match, focus on the sound that begins the next word—not the first letter.

subtopics.title: Singular Countable Nouns Require an Article
subtopics.description: When introducing a singular, countable noun for the first time, use *a* or *an* (or another determiner). You cannot leave the noun bare.

examples.explanation: Needed when the noun is new to the listener.
examples.sample: I saw a dog in the park.

examples.marker: not used with plurals the same way
examples.explanation: Plural countable nouns can appear with no article when speaking generally.

examples.marker: not used with uncountables the same way
examples.explanation: Uncountable nouns don’t take *a/an*; use *some* if needed.

subtopics.title: Use *a* Before a Consonant Sound
subtopics.description: *A* comes before words that begin with a consonant sound, regardless of spelling.

examples.explanation: Most words starting with consonant letters.
Words like *university* start with /juː/, a consonant sound.
examples.sample: He studies at a university in Canada.
It’s a historic building. (if you pronounce the h)

subtopics.title: Use *an* Before a Vowel Sound
subtopics.description: *An* comes before words that begin with a vowel sound (a, e, i, o, u sounds or silent consonants).

examples.explanation: Common before a, e, i, o, u when pronounced as vowels.
Use *an* if the word starts with a silent h (so it begins with a vowel sound).

examples.marker: an + acronym starting with vowel sound
examples.explanation: Base decision on how the letter is pronounced.

subtopics.title: Sound vs Spelling Exceptions
subtopics.description: Decide based on pronunciation, not letters. Some words that start with vowel letters take *a*; some with consonant letters take *an*.

examples.sample: He attends a university in Bogotá.
The doctor ordered an MRI scan.

subtopics.title: First Mention (New Information)
subtopics.description: Use *a/an* to introduce something new; later you can use *the* to refer to that same known thing.

examples.explanation: First time the listener hears about it.
Now the listener knows which book.
examples.sample: The book is about machine learning.

examples.explanation: A/an sets up; the continues the reference.
examples.sample: We saw a movie. The movie was hilarious.

subtopics.title: Jobs, Roles & Classifications
subtopics.description: Use *a/an* before a singular countable noun that names someone’s job, role, or category.

examples.explanation: When saying what someone does for work.
When referring to one person of that nationality.

subtopics.title: Fixed Expressions with Quantities
subtopics.description: Some quantity phrases require *a* even though the next word may be plural or uncountable.

examples.sample: We have a lot of homework.
I’ll call you in a couple of minutes.
Could I have a piece of advice?

subtopics.title: Rates, Frequency & Time Expressions
subtopics.description: Use *a* in many expressions meaning ‘per’ or ‘each.’

examples.sample: I exercise three times a week.
That car gets 40 miles a gallon.

subtopics.title: When *No Article* Is Correct
subtopics.description: Do not use *a/an* with plural nouns or uncountable nouns when speaking generally.

exercises.question: He studies at ___ university in London.
We waited for ___ hour before boarding.

exercises.instruction: Add the correct article (a / an / no article).
exercises.sentence: She is engineer and he is artist.
exercises.expected: She is an engineer and he is an artist.
